extendedIngredients.name: red chile flakes
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 tablespoon crushed dried red chile flakes

extendedIngredients.name: salt and pepper
extendedIngredients.originalString: Salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipes.title: Cilantro Scallops

winePairing.pairingText: Fish works really well with Pinot Grigio, Gruener Veltliner, and Pinot Noir. Fish is as diverse as wine, so it's hard to pick wines that go with every fish. A crisp white wine, such as a pinot grigio or Gr√ºner Veltliner, will suit any delicately flavored white fish. Meaty, strongly flavored fish such as salmon and tuna can even handle a light red wine, such as a pinot noir. You could try Chateau Ste. Michelle Pinot Gris. Reviewers quite like it with a 4 out of 5 star rating and a price of about 13 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Chateau Ste. Michelle Pinot Gris
productMatches.description: Mild winter and spring weather continued into a long, warm, dry and stable growing season in 2001. September harvest conditions were ideal with very warm, clear days and cool nights."Fresh pear, honeydew melon and mandarin orange aromas and flavors combine with chamomile tea, honeysuckle and assorted floral characteristics..." according to winemaker, Erik Olsen. This wine pairs well with shellfish, cream-based dishes, cheese & fruit.

recipes.instructions: In a medium bowl, mix together 1/4 cup olive oil, the lime juice, soy sauce, cilantro, chile flakes and garlic. Sprinkle the scallops with salt and pepper. Add the scallops to the marinade, cover with plastic and refrigerate for 30 minutes.                          Heat the remaining 1 tablespoon olive oil in medium, heavy skillet over medium-high heat. Remove the scallops from the marinade, discard the marinade, and place the scallops in the skillet. Sear until lightly browned and cooked to desired doneness, 2 to 3 minutes per side for medium-rare. Arrange the scallops decoratively on a platter and serve with lime wedges.

steps.step: In a medium bowl, mix together 1/4 cup olive oil, the lime juice, soy sauce, cilantro, chile flakes and garlic. Sprinkle the scallops with salt and pepper.
Add the scallops to the marinade, cover with plastic and refrigerate for 30 minutes.
Heat the remaining 1 tablespoon olive oil in medium, heavy skillet over medium-high heat.

Remove the scallops from the marinade, discard the marinade, and place the scallops in the skillet. Sear until lightly browned and cooked to desired doneness, 2 to 3 minutes per side for medium-rare. Arrange the scallops decoratively on a platter and serve with lime wedges.
